body.head.byline: By SAM BROWN; Written with Joe Sharkey.

abstract.p: My Job column profiles Sam Brown, horse trainer and riding instructor; Brown comments; photo (M)

block.p: Keep in mind that a horse has a little brain. You and I, as the intelligent ones, we have to come down to this horse's level. We have to try to get into this animal's head.
When giving beginner lessons, if I sense there's some fear in you, we're going to stop and have a five-minute chat:
Keep in mind that a horse has a little brain. You and I, as the intelligent ones, we have to come down to this horse's level. We have to try to get into this animal's head.
When giving beginner lessons, if I sense there's some fear in you, we're going to stop and have a five-minute chat:
''Well, some horses will never throw you, and if you're a beginner, that's probably the kind of horse you'll be on.''
''Well, you can't get kicked being on top of the horse. It is physically impossible.''

With proper instruction, anyone can ride with confidence, knowing what to do in case a horse is going and he moves laterally, which can pop you out of the saddle. I mean actually getting into this animal, actually riding this horse, toe always up, heel always down, a nice seat you work from the waist-down to ride.

I learned to ride in Central Park. I used to go down on the weekend, and I'd clean the stables and brush the horses and what-not. And my mother, she used to tear into me. She would say, ''Where'd you get this money?'' and I'd say, ''Ma, I worked for it.'' And she'd say, ''What's that smell?'' I'd come home smelling of stables.

How I got started riding, I was shining shoes down there. And I saw this guy wearing beautiful paddock boots, English boots, and I said, ''Mister, can I give you a shine?'' and he said, ''Son, all you going to do is mess up these new boots.'' Then I said, ''What you do?'' He said, ''I ride, I train horses.'' I said, ''Maybe you'll take me out to ride on a horse?'' He said, ''O.K., how about tomorrow?'' I said, ''I can't go tomorrow, tomorrow's school.''

A kid who stays out of school today, it's different. Back then, a kid stayed out of school, the truant officer came to the house. But that one time I played hooky, I went riding with this guy, and he says, ''Kid, you're a natural.'' That was the beginning.

The rich at that time were different than the rich of today. They were not as snobbish as today, they could recognize, ''That's young Sam, he rides here, and he's a good kid.'' That wouldn't happen today to a kid like me who just wanted to ride in Central Park. The rich today, they're too much into protecting their turf.

I love horses. I understand them. I don't sentimentalize them. I don't kiss a horse. Every now and then I'll give them a little pat. A horse has no emotions, no nothing, he's just a beast of burden with a little brain the size of a walnut. I don't want to get attached to that animal because I get attached I'll never sell him. But I do keep a scrapbook with pictures of most of the horses I have owned in it.

MY JOB Correction: June 10, 2000, Saturday The My Job column on the Workplace page on May 31 about Sam Brown, a horse trainer and riding instructor, omitted the identity of his employers. They are the Montclair Riding Academy in New Jersey and Cedar Lane Stables in Brooklyn.
